content.title: Ruptured AAA Management Algorithm
content.description: Systematic approach to the diagnosis and treatment of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm, one of the most lethal vascular emergencies.
content.definition: Ruptured AAA management requires rapid diagnosis, resuscitation with permissive hypotension, and emergent repair either via open surgery or endovascular repair (rEVAR) depending on patient stability and anatomic suitability.

classic_presentation: Sudden severe abdominal or back pain
Hypotension (may be initially normotensive if contained)
Classic triad: pain, hypotension, pulsatile mass (present in 30-50%)
hemodynamic_categories: Stable (SBP >80): May undergo imaging if highly suspicious
Moribund (SBP <60): Immediate surgery or REBOA as bridge
management_principles: Limit crystalloid resuscitation to avoid 'popping the clot'
EVAR-first strategy if anatomically suitable and available
Open repair for unsuitable anatomy or unstable patients

learning_objectives: Recognize classic and atypical ruptured AAA presentations
Determine EVAR vs open repair candidacy
clinical_pearls: 50% of ruptured AAAs die before reaching hospital
Permissive hypotension delays clot disruption until aortic control
rEVAR mortality is similar or lower than open repair in suitable anatomy
REBOA can provide temporizing aortic control in extremis
